Award.AwardTitle: MSB/PEET: PolyPEET: Enhancing taxonomic expertise in the Polyporales
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Polyporales is a diverse group of fungi that includes "bracket fungi," crust-like forms, gilled mushrooms, and others. Recent years have seen much new information on how the major groups of polypores are related to each other, but genus-level classification remains poorly resolved, and it is likely that many species remain undiscovered. To understand the diversity of Polyporales, classical taxonomic approaches must be combined with morphology and modern molecular methods. Unfortunately, however, few mycologists have expertise in both areas, and many of the world's experts are retired or are nearing retirement. The goals of this project are: 1) To train the next generation of fungal taxonomists with expertise in morphological and molecular methods; 2) To produce comprehensive monographs of selected genera of Polyporales; 3) To create informatics resources for mycologists and the general public; 4) To promote development of an international community of Polyporales taxonomists; 5) To encourage participation in science by members of underrepresented groups; and, 6) To raise awareness about mycology among high school students and educators. The proposed research and training activities will be conducted by an international team of four "Principal Collaborators," and five "Trainees," including three PhD students and two early-career post-doctoral researchers.

As decayers and pathogens, Fungi have profound impacts on human affairs. They also function as beneficial symbionts, provide food, drugs, and other useful biochemicals, and serve as model systems for genetics and molecular biology. However, it is estimated that only 5-10% of the species of Fungi have been described. The Polyporales contains many wood-decay fungi, as well as timber pathogens. They play an important role in the carbon cycle, and produce diverse enzymes that break down lignin and cellulose. Monographic studies in Polyporales will improve understanding of biodiversity and will provide resources for applied research into biofuel production, bioremediation, and other "green" technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “PolyPEET” project focused on the diversity and evolutionary relationships of mushroom-forming fungi in the order Polyporales, and other ecologically similar groups. As wood-decay fungi, Polyporales are of profound ecological importance, because they provide a key link in the carbon cycle. They are also of interest to molecular biologists and biofuels researchers, because their enzymes may be of use in industrial processes (e.g., production of cellulosic ethanol). Polypores are conspicuous forest fungi, and they have been well studied. Nevertheless, the taxonomy and evolutionary relationships of Polyporales have been unsettled. The absence of a consensus classification for the group is an impediment to research and communication. The PolyPEET project sought to reconstruct evolutionary relationships of Polyporales and translate phylogenetic (evolutionary) trees into classifications. This project also had a significant training and outreach component, described below.

Intellectual merit:

The PolyPEET project resulted in approximately 32 articles in peer-reviewed journals (as of this writing, several are still in review) and numerous presentations at scientific conferences. Core articles presented comprehensive phylogenetic trees for the entire group, as well as analyses of groups within the Polyporales (Phanerochaetaceae, Trametes, and the “Antrodia clade”). The classifications resulting from this work will promote communication among all researchers with interests in wood-decay fungi, not only fungal taxonomists,

In addition to phylogenetic analyses, the project incorporated a comparative genomic perspective, reporting new genomes for several species within Polyporales, as well as an endophyte of the tropical rubber tree, Hevea brasiliensis. Several of these papers combining genomic and systematic analyses were published in a special section of the journal Mycologia (see the attached image). Other aspects of the project included DNA sequence-based characterization of communities of fungi living as endophytes in the sapwood of H. brasiliensis. Related to this work, we produced several articles addressing the utility of DNA sequences for classification and identification of all fungi, not just Polyporales. 

Broader impacts: 

The PolyPEET project had a major focus on training and outreach. Over the course of the project five main “trainees” received direct support, including three PhD students (one based at Clark and two from collaborating institutions; all three graduated with their PhDs during the project period) and two postdoctoral researchers. Four undergraduates at Clark University also participated directly in this project. A group of five senior colleagues from other institutions also participated in advisory roles. Thus, this project promoted the development of an international community of researchers with interests in wood decay fungi, who continue to collaborate.

Outreach was accomplished through mushroom forays involving the Boston Mycological Club, Northeast Mycological Federation, North American Mycological Association, and the Worcester EcoTarium. Members of the Hibbett laboratory at Clark led mushroom forays in each year of the project. The Hibbett laboratory routinely consults with local citizens regarding mushroom identification.

Information resources produced in this project include whole genome sequences of wood decay fungi, which may be of utility for applied research, including that aimed at biofuel production.
